BIOL410 examines the mechanisms of evolution, from the genetic level to the population level. It examines the theory and practice of concepts such as natural selection, population structure, gene flow, and quantitative genetics. BIOL230 (Evolutionary Biology) is a prerequisite for the class.

All reviewers enjoyed the course, calling it “very interesting,” very exciting,” “well structured,” and overall a “terrific course.” Some felt there was so much material that the course could be split into two separate classes so that more material could be addressed in greater depth. Often, topics were covered quickly and “not in too much depth,” according to one students. Some reviewers found the first portion of the class too formula-intensive without deriving the underlying concepts, making application of formulas to problems a little confusing.

The two instructors for the class both received praise from reviewers, who wrote that Professors Plotkin and Sniegowski were “wonderful,” “excellent,” and “approachable.” One student wrote that Professor Sniegowski could have used a little more organization, emphasizing important points and making sure that homework was directly tied to what was learned in lecture. However, the same student said, “Dr. Sniegowski particularly enjoys talking to students.”

This class appeared to attract mostly biology majors, who thought that the material was “accessible to biologists.”
